home.title: Home
home.description: Bezstresowo Psychotherapy Center - professional psychological support and psychotherapy with empathy and understanding

aboutMe.title: About Me
description: I am a psychotherapist in training at the International Transactional Analysis Association. I provide individual psychotherapy for women, group psychotherapy for adolescents and adults, as well as psychotherapy for couples.

I work with individuals who struggle with eating disorders, anxiety disorders, difficulties in defining identity and expressing emotions, depression, anxiety states, codependent relationships, low self-esteem, social difficulties, and traumatic experiences. I also fully support people from the LGBT+ community, providing them with a space based on acceptance, understanding, and professional support.

I specialize in the transactional analysis approach, which is based on helping clients become familiar with the patterns present in their own behavior and that of their environment, especially in communication, as well as the roles we take on in relationships. In my work, I adhere to the psychotherapist’s code of ethics and build a therapeutic space with clients founded on trust, a sense of safety, and acceptance.

In order to maintain the highest standards of my work, I continuously develop my skills by participating in numerous courses, conferences, and professional trainings. I work under the constant supervision of qualified supervisors.

My priority is always to provide clients with a safe and supportive space in which they can feel understood and accepted. In my work, I am guided by high ethical standards, full respect, and commitment. With passion and professionalism, I support individuals in improving their quality of life and in the process of coping with difficulties, both emotional and social. I warmly invite you to get in touch and begin a shared journey toward better well-being and mental health. I offer help by providing support tailored to individual needs.

couplesTherapy.title: Couple Psychotherapy
couplesTherapy.description: Support in resolving conflicts, improving communication, and rebuilding connection within the relationship. Sessions are held in a safe and supportive environment.

section0.title: What is couples therapy?
section0.paragraph0: It is a space where partners can safely examine their relationship. Whether you are married, in a long-term partnership, or just beginning your journey together — if difficulties arise, therapy can help you regain closeness and understanding. Sessions allow you to discover the causes of conflicts, rebuild trust, and find new ways of communicating.

section1.title: Who is it for?
section1.paragraph0: Couples therapy can be helpful if:
list0: you frequently have arguments, misunderstandings, or emotional distance,
you feel lonely or misunderstood in the relationship,
you are going through a crisis — related to infidelity, sexual problems, parenting difficulties, illness, or loss,
you want to improve the quality of your relationship before problems deepen,
you are at a crossroads and considering the future of your relationship.

section2.title: What does the therapy process look like?
list0: Sessions are held together — both partners meet with the therapist.
The first meetings are for learning about your relationship history and determining what you want to work on.
During therapy, you learn open communication, expressing emotions, and resolving conflicts constructively.
The therapist does not take sides — they create a neutral and safe space where both of you can speak and be heard.

section3.title: Goals of therapy:
list0: better understanding of each other and improved communication,
rebuilding closeness and trust,
learning to resolve conflicts in a healthy way,
strengthening the partnership and emotional bond,
making a conscious decision about the future of the relationship.

womenTherapy.title: Psychotherapy for Women
womenTherapy.description: Individual therapy supporting women in building self-worth, setting boundaries, and regaining inner balance in a safe atmosphere of understanding.

section0.paragraph0: Psychotherapy for women is an individual therapeutic process aimed at women who experience emotional, relational, or life crisis difficulties. It is a form of professional psychological help where you can safely examine your emotions, behavioral patterns, and relationships in an atmosphere of understanding, confidentiality, and respect.
section0.paragraph1: If you feel exhausted by constant tension, excessive responsibility, difficult relationships, or the struggle with yourself — psychotherapy can help you reconnect with yourself and introduce real changes in your daily life.

section1.title: Who is psychotherapy for women for?
section1.paragraph0: Women who benefit from psychotherapy include those who, among others:
list0: struggle with low self-esteem
experience difficulties in romantic or family relationships
have trouble setting boundaries and putting themselves first
feel chronic stress, anxiety, emotional tension, or emptiness
are in a life crisis, after a breakup, or during important changes
experience a difficult relationship with their body or food
section1.paragraph1: Psychotherapy for women is also for those who "function well" but internally feel that something is wrong and want to understand themselves better.

section2.title: Areas of work in psychotherapy for women
section2.paragraph1: Working on recurring patterns in relationships, difficulties with closeness, fear of rejection, toxic relationships, and codependency.
section2.paragraph3: Support in building healthy self-esteem, working with perfectionism, excessive people-pleasing, and difficulty saying "no".
section2.paragraph5: Psychotherapy helps in understanding and regulating emotions such as anxiety, anger, shame, sadness, or guilt, as well as working with chronic tension and mental overload.
section2.paragraph7: Therapeutic work in the area of eating disorders, compulsive eating, restriction, control, and a difficult relationship with one's own body.
section2.paragraph9: Psychotherapy for women who feel compelled to be strong, independent, and responsible at the expense of their own needs, rest, and emotions.
section2.paragraph11: Support during breakups, professional burnout, changing life roles, feeling stuck, or loss of meaning.

section3.title: What does psychotherapy for women look like?
section3.paragraph0: Psychotherapy is a process based on regular sessions, tailored to your needs and pace. You don't need to know exactly what the problem is — a willingness to look at yourself with curiosity and mindfulness is enough.
section3.paragraph1: The goal of psychotherapy is not to "fix" you, but to understand the mechanisms that were created to protect you, and to gradually build a more supportive relationship with yourself and others.

depressionTherapy.title: Psychotherapy for Depression and Anxiety Disorders
depressionTherapy.description: Professional support in regaining emotional balance and building effective tools for coping with anxiety and depression.

section0.paragraph0: Psychotherapy for depression and anxiety disorders is a form of specialized psychological support aimed at people struggling with low mood, anxiety, emotional tension, or a sense of helplessness. Therapy helps understand the causes of difficulties, learn to regulate emotions, and gradually regain a sense of control over one's own life.
section0.paragraph1: Depression and anxiety disorders are not signs of weakness. They are often a reaction to prolonged stress, overload, difficult experiences, or unrecognized needs. Psychotherapy allows working not only with symptoms but also with their source.

section1.title: Who is psychotherapy for depression and anxiety for?
section1.paragraph0: People who benefit from psychotherapy for depression and anxiety disorders include those who:
list0: experience prolonged sadness, emptiness, or lack of energy
feel intense anxiety, tension, restlessness, or panic attacks
have difficulty concentrating, sleeping, or functioning daily
feel a loss of meaning, motivation, or joy in life
struggle with excessive worrying and control
avoid situations due to anxiety or mental exhaustion
section1.paragraph1: Psychotherapy is also for people who do not have a formal diagnosis but feel that their mental state significantly affects their quality of life.

section2.title: Areas of work in psychotherapy for depression and anxiety disorders:
section2.paragraph1: Working with low mood, feelings of worthlessness, lack of energy, excessive guilt, inner criticism, and withdrawal from relationships.
section2.paragraph3: Support in working with generalized anxiety, panic attacks, social anxiety, phobias, and chronic mental tension.
section2.paragraph5: Recognizing and modifying thought patterns that maintain anxiety, helplessness, or a sense of threat.
section2.paragraph7: Learning safe ways to cope with intense emotions, bodily tension, and mental overload.
section2.paragraph9: Understanding how relationships, over-responsibility, or lack of boundaries affect the intensity of depressive and anxiety symptoms.
section2.paragraph11: Working with burnout, prolonged stress, life changes, loss, or feeling stuck.

section3.title: What does psychotherapy for depression and anxiety disorders look like?
section3.paragraph0: Psychotherapy is a process based on regular sessions, adapted to your current abilities and pace. It does not require "being ready" or precisely naming the problem at the beginning.
list0: reducing the severity of symptoms
better understanding of your own reactions and emotions
rebuilding a sense of safety and stability
improving quality of life and daily functioning
section3.paragraph2: If needed, therapy can be conducted in collaboration with a psychiatrist.

section4.title: Psychotherapy for depression and anxiety — important information
list0: You don't have to "cope on your own" to deserve help
Symptoms are a signal, not a failure
Therapy doesn't rush — we work at a safe pace
Every process is individual

lgbtTherapy.title: Psychotherapy for LGBTQ+ Individuals
lgbtTherapy.description: Affirmative psychological support for LGBTQ+ individuals, helping build self-acceptance and well-being in a safe, judgment-free atmosphere.

section0.paragraph0: Psychotherapy for LGBTQ+ individuals is an individual form of psychological support aimed at non-heteronormative and transgender people who want to work on their mental well-being, relationships, identity, or difficult life experiences. It is a safe space free from judgment, pathologizing, and attempts to "fix" anyone.
section0.paragraph1: Therapy is not about changing orientation or identity. Its goal is to support coping with emotions, minority stress, relationships, and the effects of discrimination or rejection.

section1.title: Who is psychotherapy for LGBTQ+ individuals for?
section1.paragraph0: People who benefit from psychotherapy for LGBTQ+ individuals include those who:
list0: experience emotional difficulties, anxiety, or low mood
struggle with feelings of shame, guilt, or lack of self-acceptance
are in the process of coming out or dealing with their environment's reaction
have experienced rejection, discrimination, or violence
have difficulties in romantic or family relationships
feel overwhelmed by constantly "explaining themselves" or hiding who they are
section1.paragraph1: Psychotherapy is also for those who are not going through a crisis but want to understand themselves better and live in greater harmony with themselves.

section2.title: Areas of work in psychotherapy for LGBTQ+ individuals
section2.paragraph1: Working on building a stable sense of self-worth, accepting one's psychosexual orientation or gender identity.
section2.paragraph3: Support in coping with chronic tension resulting from living in a society that can be unfriendly or judgmental.
section2.paragraph5: Difficulties in partnerships, fear of rejection, problems with trust, communication, and boundaries in relationships.
section2.paragraph7: Working with family reactions, fear of disclosure, feelings of loss, grief, or lack of support from loved ones.
section2.paragraph9: Anxiety, anger, sadness, shame, feeling of loneliness — therapy helps safely experience and regulate them.
section2.paragraph11: Support in working with the consequences of psychological, physical, or sexual violence, hate, and microaggressions.

section3.title: What does LGBTQ+ psychotherapy look like?
section3.paragraph0: Psychotherapy is based on respect, knowledge, and understanding of the specifics of LGBTQ+ experiences. Sessions take place at a pace tailored to you and your needs.
list0: improving mental well-being
strengthening a sense of safety and agency
building healthier relationships
greater alignment with one's own values and identity

section4.title: Important information
list0: You don't need to have a "serious problem" to benefit from therapy
Your identity is not a diagnosis
Therapy is a confidential and supportive space
You have the right to support without having to explain who you are

parentTherapy.title: Psychotherapy and Consultations for Parents
parentTherapy.description: Professional support helping parents understand their child's emotions, cope with parenting challenges, and build healthier family relationships in a judgment-free atmosphere.

section0.paragraph0: Psychotherapy for parents is a form of professional psychotherapeutic support aimed at people who want to better understand their child, improve family relationships, and cope with parenting and emotional difficulties. It is a space where you can look not only at the child's behavior but also at your own emotions, reactions, and sense of responsibility.
section0.paragraph1: Parenting can be overwhelming, full of doubts, tension, and guilt. Psychotherapy helps organize the chaos, regain peace, and find more supportive ways of reacting — without judgment and ready-made recipes.

section1.title: Who is therapy for parents for?
section1.paragraph0: People who benefit from therapy or consultations for parents include those who:
list0: experience parenting difficulties with a child or teenager
feel helplessness, anger, anxiety, or overwhelm in the parenting role
struggle with communication problems in the family
worry about the child's behavior, emotions, or functioning
want to set boundaries better without feeling guilty
are going through a family crisis, separation, or a change in life situation
section1.paragraph1: Therapy for parents does not mean that "you're doing something wrong." It is a sign that you want to act consciously and responsibly.

section2.title: Areas of work in therapy for parents
section2.paragraph1: Support in understanding difficult child behaviors, emotional outbursts, withdrawal, aggression, or adaptation problems.
section2.paragraph3: Working on improving emotional contact, communication, sense of safety, and trust in the relationship.
section2.paragraph5: Help in setting clear boundaries without excessive strictness or submissiveness, building parenting consistency.
section2.paragraph7: Working with guilt, helplessness, anger, worry about the child, and parental burnout.
section2.paragraph9: Support during divorce, family conflicts, life changes, illness, or the child's emotional crises.
section2.paragraph10: The parent and their own childhood experiences
section2.paragraph11: Understanding how your own experiences affect the way you react and raise your child.

section3.title: What does therapy for parents look like?
section3.paragraph0: Therapy for parents can take the form of:
list0: single consultations
short-term support
a longer psychotherapeutic process
section3.paragraph1: Sessions focus on the specific difficulties you bring and on building real, implementable changes. The child's well-being always remains at the center, but without ignoring the parent's needs and boundaries.

section4.title: Support for parents — important information:
list0: You don't have to come with your child
You don't need a "serious problem" to seek help
A change on the parent's side often triggers a change in the child
Therapy does not judge the way of parenting — it helps understand and regain positive influence.

eatingDisorderTherapy.title: Psychotherapy for Eating Disorders
eatingDisorderTherapy.description: Specialized therapy helping to understand the emotional causes of eating disorders and rebuild a safe relationship with food and one's own body.

section0.paragraph0: Psychotherapy for eating disorders is a specialized form of psychotherapy aimed at people struggling with a difficult relationship with food, body, and control. It is a process that helps understand the emotional and psychological mechanisms behind the symptoms and gradually regain a sense of safety, control, and connection with oneself.
section0.paragraph1: Eating disorders are not a problem of "lacking willpower." They are often a way of coping with tension, emotions, relationships, or a sense of lack of control. Psychotherapy allows reaching the source of the problem, not just stopping the symptoms.

section1.title: Who is eating disorder therapy for?
section1.paragraph0: People who benefit from eating disorder therapy include those who:
list0: struggle with anorexia, bulimia, or binge eating disorder
experience compulsive eating or dietary restrictions
have obsessive thoughts about food, weight, or appearance
feel intense guilt, shame, or anxiety related to food
excessively control their body, workouts, or diet
feel a loss of control over eating or, conversely, a rigid need for control
section1.paragraph1: Therapy is also for people who do not formally have a diagnosis but feel that food and body take up too much space in their life.

section2.title: Areas of work in eating disorder therapy
section2.paragraph1: Working on restrictions, compulsions, binge eating episodes, guilt after eating, and fear of losing control.
section2.paragraph3: Support in building a more realistic and gentle connection with one's own body, working with body image, shame, and excessive self-criticism.
section2.paragraph5: Eating disorders often serve the function of regulating emotions. Therapy helps learn to recognize, name, and safely experience emotions.
section2.paragraph7: Working with an excessive need for control, high self-expectations, and the feeling that "I have to earn being enough."
section2.paragraph9: Understanding how relationships and past experiences influence the way body and food become a place of tension or escape.

section3.title: What does eating disorder therapy look like?
section3.paragraph0: Eating disorder therapy is a long-term process based on safety, trust, and an individual pace of work. It does not involve controlling food or imposing ready-made schemes.
list0: reducing or extinguishing symptoms
understanding the function of eating disorders
rebuilding a sense of control and agency
creating a safer relationship with food and the body
section3.paragraph2: If needed, therapy can be conducted in collaboration with a doctor or dietitian.

controller.title: 1. The data controller is Bezstresowo Psychotherapy Center - Olesya Haiduk.

purpose.title: 2. Personal data is processed for the purpose of:
items: providing psychotherapy services,
organizational contact,
fulfilling accounting and legal obligations.

legal.title: 3. The basis for data processing is the Client's consent, contract performance, and the Controller's legal obligation.

recipients.title: 4. Data is not transferred to third parties, except to entities authorized by law.

rights.title: 5. The Client has the right to access data, correct it, delete it, restrict processing, transfer it, and withdraw consent.

complaint.title: 6. The Client has the right to lodge a complaint with the President of the Personal Data Protection Office.

termsOfService.title: Terms of Psychotherapy Services
termsOfService.subtitle: Bezstresowo Psychotherapy Center - Olesya Haiduk
termsOfService.description: Terms and conditions for the provision of psychotherapy services

general.title: §1 General Provisions
items: These Terms define the rules for providing psychotherapy services by Bezstresowo Psychotherapy Center - Olesya Haiduk, hereinafter referred to as the "Therapist".
The Client is a person using psychotherapy services, hereinafter referred to as the "Client".
Using the services means acceptance of these Terms.

scope.title: §2 Scope of Services
scope.intro: Services are provided by a psychotherapist trained in Transactional Analysis, working in accordance with ethical standards and under the constant supervision of supervisors. Sessions are held in-person or online.
scope.servicesTitle: Services provided by the Center include:
services: psychotherapy for women in difficult relationships;
psychotherapy for depression and anxiety disorders;
psychotherapy for Adult Children of Dysfunctional Families;

nature.title: §3 Nature of Psychotherapy Services
items: Psychotherapy is a process of psychological support, working on emotional and relational difficulties, and the effects of traumatic experiences.
Services provided by the Therapist are not medical services and do not replace psychiatric treatment or pharmacotherapy.
The Therapist does not issue prescriptions, sick leaves, certificates, or court opinions.
Psychotherapy does not guarantee specific results - its effects are individual.

trauma.title: §4 Trauma Therapy and Client Safety
items: The Client is aware that the psychotherapy process, especially in the area of traumatic experience, may involve experiencing strong emotions, temporary deterioration of well-being, or the emergence of difficult memories.
In emergency situations, the Client is obliged to immediately contact emergency numbers (112) or medical facilities.
The Therapist may recommend psychiatric consultation or another form of specialized help.

cooperation.title: §5 Rules of Therapeutic Cooperation
items: Psychotherapy is based on voluntariness, confidentiality, mutual respect, and clearly defined boundaries.
The Client commits to active participation in the therapeutic process and honest communication.
The therapeutic relationship is exclusively professional: no private or social relationships are established outside of sessions.
Contact with the Therapist takes place only in agreed forms and hours.

appointments.title: §6 Scheduling and Cancelling Appointments
items: Session dates are arranged individually.
The Client is required to cancel an appointment at least 24 hours before the scheduled time.
In case of not cancelling an appointment or cancelling it after this time, the Therapist has the right to charge the full fee.
Client's lateness does not extend the session.

fees.title: §7 Fees
items: The current price list is available on the website or provided to the Client before starting cooperation.
The session fee is paid in the agreed form.
The Therapist reserves the right to change prices, informing the Client in advance.

online.title: §8 Online Sessions
items: Online sessions are held via an agreed communication platform.
The Client is obliged to ensure private, safe conditions for the conversation and a stable internet connection.
The Therapist is not responsible for technical problems on the Client's side.

confidentiality.title: §9 Confidentiality and Professional Secrecy
items: All information provided by the Client is covered by professional secrecy.
Confidentiality may be breached only in cases provided for by law (e.g., threat to life).

liability.title: §10 Liability
items: The Therapist is not responsible for decisions made by the Client outside the therapeutic process.
Psychotherapy is not a form of legal, financial, or medical advice.

final.title: §11 Final Provisions
items: These Terms may be amended.
The current version of the Terms is available on the Center's website.
Matters not regulated by these Terms are governed by Polish law.

download.title: Download Full Terms
download.description: You can download the full terms of psychotherapy services in PDF format.
download.languageNote: The PDF document is available in Polish.
